event.descr:
The BGP Established event is generated when the BGP FSM enters the ESTABLISHED state.

bgpPeerLastError %parm[#1]%;

bgpPeerState %parm[#2]%;
event.logmsg: bgpEstablishedV1 trap received bgpPeerLastError=%parm[#1]% bgpPeerState=%parm[#2]%

event.descr:
The BGPBackwardTransition Event is generated when the BGP FSM moves from a higher numbered state to a lower numbered state.

bgpPeerLastError %parm[#1]%;

bgpPeerState %parm[#2]%;
event.logmsg: bgpBackwardTransitionV1 trap received bgpPeerLastError=%parm[#1]% bgpPeerState=%parm[#2]%

event.descr:
A jnxPowerSupplyFailure trap signifies that the specified power supply in the chassis has been in the failure (bad DC output) condition.

jnxContentsContainerIndex %parm[#1]%;

jnxContentsL1Index %parm[#2]%;

jnxContentsL2Index %parm[#3]%;

jnxContentsL3Index %parm[#4]%;

jnxContentsDescr %parm[#5]%;
event.logmsg: jnxPowerSupplyFailureV1 trap received jnxContentsContainerIndex=%parm[#1]% jnxContentsL1Index=%parm[#2]% jnxContentsL2Index=%parm[#3]% jnxContentsL3Index=%parm[#4]% jnxContentsDescr=%parm[#5]%

event.descr:
A jnxFanFailure trap signifies that the specified cooling fan or impeller in the chassis has been in the failure (not spinning) condition.

jnxContentsContainerIndex %parm[#1]%;

jnxContentsL1Index %parm[#2]%;

jnxContentsL2Index %parm[#3]%;

jnxContentsL3Index %parm[#4]%;

jnxContentsDescr %parm[#5]%;
event.logmsg: jnxFanFailureV1 trap received jnxContentsContainerIndex=%parm[#1]% jnxContentsL1Index=%parm[#2]% jnxContentsL2Index=%parm[#3]% jnxContentsL3Index=%parm[#4]% jnxContentsDescr=%parm[#5]%

event.descr:
A jnxOverTemperature trap signifies that the specified hardware component in the chassis has experienced over temperature condition.

jnxContentsContainerIndex %parm[#1]%;

jnxContentsL1Index %parm[#2]%;

jnxContentsL2Index %parm[#3]%;

jnxContentsL3Index %parm[#4]%;

jnxContentsDescr %parm[#5]%;
event.logmsg: jnxOverTemperatureV1 trap received jnxContentsContainerIndex=%parm[#1]% jnxContentsL1Index=%parm[#2]% jnxContentsL2Index=%parm[#3]% jnxContentsL3Index=%parm[#4]% jnxContentsDescr=%parm[#5]%

event.descr:
An mplsLspUp trap signifies that the specified LSP is up. The current active path for the LSP is mplsPathName.

mplsLspName %parm[#1]%;

mplsPathName %parm[#2]%;
event.logmsg: mplsLspUpV1 trap received mplsLspName=%parm[#1]% mplsPathName=%parm[#2]%

event.descr:
An mplsLspDown trap signifies that the specified LSP is down, because the current active path mplsPathName went down.

mplsLspName %parm[#1]%;

mplsPathName %parm[#2]%;
event.logmsg: mplsLspDownV1 trap received mplsLspName=%parm[#1]% mplsPathName=%parm[#2]%

event.descr:
An mplsLspChange trap signifies that the the specified LSP has switched traffic to the new active path 'toLspPath'. The LSP maintains up state before and after the switch over

mplsLspName %parm[#1]%;

mplsPathName %parm[#2]%;
event.logmsg: mplsLspChangeV1 trap received mplsLspName=%parm[#1]% mplsPathName=%parm[#2]%

event.descr:
An ospfIfStateChange trap signifies that there has been a change in the state of an OSPF vir- tual interface. This trap should be generated when the inter- face state regresses (e.g., goes from Point- to-Point to Down) or progresses to a terminal state (i.e., Point-to-Point).

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfVirtIfAreaId %parm[#2]%;

ospfVirtIfNeighbor %parm[#3]%;

ospfVirtIfState %parm[#4]%;
event.logmsg: ospfVirtIfStateChangeV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfVirtIfAreaId=%parm[#2]% ospfVirtIfNeighbor=%parm[#3]% ospfVirtIfState=%parm[#4]%

event.descr:
An ospfNbrStateChange trap signifies that there has been a change in the state of a non- virtual OSPF neighbor. This trap should be generated when the neighbor state regresses (e.g., goes from Attempt or Full to 1-Way or Down) or progresses to a terminal state (e.g., 2-Way or Full). When an neighbor transitions from or to Full on non-broadcast multi-access and broadcast networks, the trap should be gen- erated by the designated router. A designated router transitioning to Down will be noted by ospfIfStateChange.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfNbrIpAddr %parm[#2]%;

ospfNbrAddressLessIndex %parm[#3]%;

ospfNbrRtrId %parm[#4]%;

ospfNbrState %parm[#5]%;
event.logmsg: ospfNbrStateChangeV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfNbrIpAddr=%parm[#2]% ospfNbrAddressLessIndex=%parm[#3]% ospfNbrRtrId=%parm[#4]% ospfNbrState=%parm[#5]%

event.descr:
An ospfIfStateChange trap signifies that there has been a change in the state of an OSPF vir- tual neighbor. This trap should be generated when the neighbor state regresses (e.g., goes from Attempt or Full to 1-Way or Down) or progresses to a terminal state (e.g., Full).

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfVirtNbrArea %parm[#2]%;

ospfVirtNbrRtrId %parm[#3]%;

ospfVirtNbrState %parm[#4]%;
event.logmsg: ospfVirtNbrStateChangeV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfVirtNbrArea=%parm[#2]% ospfVirtNbrRtrId=%parm[#3]% ospfVirtNbrState=%parm[#4]%

event.descr:
An ospfIfConfigError trap signifies that a packet has been received on a non-virtual in- terface from a router whose configuration parameters conflict with this router's confi- guration parameters. Note that the event op- tionMismatch should cause a trap only if it prevents an adjacency from forming.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfIfIpAddress %parm[#2]%;

ospfAddressLessIf %parm[#3]%;

ospfPacketSrc %parm[#4]%;

ospfConfigErrorType %parm[#5]%;

ospfPacketType %parm[#6]%;
event.logmsg: ospfIfConfigErrorV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfIfIpAddress=%parm[#2]% ospfAddressLessIf=%parm[#3]% ospfPacketSrc=%parm[#4]% ospfConfigErrorType=%parm[#5]% ospfPacketType=%parm[#6]%

event.descr:
An ospfConfigError trap signifies that a pack- et has been received on a virtual interface from a router whose configuration parameters conflict with this router's configuration parameters. Note that the event optionMismatch should cause a trap only if it prevents an ad- jacency from forming.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfVirtIfAreaId %parm[#2]%;

ospfVirtIfNeighbor %parm[#3]%;

ospfConfigErrorType %parm[#4]%;

ospfPacketType %parm[#5]%;
event.logmsg: ospfVirtIfConfigErrorV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfVirtIfAreaId=%parm[#2]% ospfVirtIfNeighbor=%parm[#3]% ospfConfigErrorType=%parm[#4]% ospfPacketType=%parm[#5]%

event.descr:
An ospfIfAuthFailure trap signifies that a packet has been received on a non-virtual in- terface from a router whose authentication key or authentication type conflicts with this router's authentication key or authentication type.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfIfIpAddress %parm[#2]%;

ospfAddressLessIf %parm[#3]%;

ospfPacketSrc %parm[#4]%;

ospfConfigErrorType %parm[#5]%;

ospfPacketType %parm[#6]%;
event.logmsg: ospfIfAuthFailureV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfIfIpAddress=%parm[#2]% ospfAddressLessIf=%parm[#3]% ospfPacketSrc=%parm[#4]% ospfConfigErrorType=%parm[#5]% ospfPacketType=%parm[#6]%

event.descr:
An ospfVirtIfAuthFailure trap signifies that a packet has been received on a virtual interface from a router whose authentication key or au- thentication type conflicts with this router's authentication key or authentication type.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfVirtIfAreaId %parm[#2]%;

ospfVirtIfNeighbor %parm[#3]%;

ospfConfigErrorType %parm[#4]%;

ospfPacketType %parm[#5]%;
event.logmsg: ospfVirtIfAuthFailureV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfVirtIfAreaId=%parm[#2]% ospfVirtIfNeighbor=%parm[#3]% ospfConfigErrorType=%parm[#4]% ospfPacketType=%parm[#5]%

event.descr:
An ospfIfRxBadPacket trap signifies that an OSPF packet has been received on a non-virtual interface that cannot be parsed.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfIfIpAddress %parm[#2]%;

ospfAddressLessIf %parm[#3]%;

ospfPacketSrc %parm[#4]%;

ospfPacketType %parm[#5]%;
event.logmsg: ospfIfRxBadPacketV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfIfIpAddress=%parm[#2]% ospfAddressLessIf=%parm[#3]% ospfPacketSrc=%parm[#4]% ospfPacketType=%parm[#5]%

event.descr:
An ospfRxBadPacket trap signifies that an OSPF packet has been received on a virtual interface that cannot be parsed.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfVirtIfAreaId %parm[#2]%;

ospfVirtIfNeighbor %parm[#3]%;

ospfPacketType %parm[#4]%;
event.logmsg: ospfVirtIfRxBadPacketV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfVirtIfAreaId=%parm[#2]% ospfVirtIfNeighbor=%parm[#3]% ospfPacketType=%parm[#4]%

event.descr:
An ospfTxRetransmit trap signifies than an OSPF packet has been retransmitted on a non- virtual interface. All packets that may be re- transmitted are associated with an LSDB entry. The LS type, LS ID, and Router ID are used to identify the LSDB entry.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfIfIpAddress %parm[#2]%;

ospfAddressLessIf %parm[#3]%;

ospfNbrRtrId %parm[#4]%;

ospfPacketType %parm[#5]%;

ospfLsdbType %parm[#6]%;

ospfLsdbLsid %parm[#7]%;

ospfLsdbRouterId %parm[#8]%;
event.logmsg: ospfTxRetransmitV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfIfIpAddress=%parm[#2]% ospfAddressLessIf=%parm[#3]% ospfNbrRtrId=%parm[#4]% ospfPacketType=%parm[#5]% ospfLsdbType=%parm[#6]% ospfLsdbLsid=%parm[#7]% ospfLsdbRouterId=%parm[#8]%

event.descr:
An ospfTxRetransmit trap signifies than an OSPF packet has been retransmitted on a virtual interface. All packets that may be retransmit- ted are associated with an LSDB entry. The LS type, LS ID, and Router ID are used to identify the LSDB entry.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfVirtIfAreaId %parm[#2]%;

ospfVirtIfNeighbor %parm[#3]%;

ospfPacketType %parm[#4]%;

ospfLsdbType %parm[#5]%;

ospfLsdbLsid %parm[#6]%;

ospfLsdbRouterId %parm[#7]%;
event.logmsg: ospfVirtIfTxRetransmitV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfVirtIfAreaId=%parm[#2]% ospfVirtIfNeighbor=%parm[#3]% ospfPacketType=%parm[#4]% ospfLsdbType=%parm[#5]% ospfLsdbLsid=%parm[#6]% ospfLsdbRouterId=%parm[#7]%

event.descr:
An ospfOriginateLsa trap signifies that a new LSA has been originated by this router. This trap should not be invoked for simple refreshes of LSAs (which happesn every 30 minutes), but instead will only be invoked when an LSA is (re)originated due to a topology change. Addi- tionally, this trap does not include LSAs that are being flushed because they have reached MaxAge.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfLsdbAreaId %parm[#2]%;

ospfLsdbType %parm[#3]%;

ospfLsdbLsid %parm[#4]%;

ospfLsdbRouterId %parm[#5]%;
event.logmsg: ospfOriginateLsaV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfLsdbAreaId=%parm[#2]% ospfLsdbType=%parm[#3]% ospfLsdbLsid=%parm[#4]% ospfLsdbRouterId=%parm[#5]%

event.descr:
An ospfMaxAgeLsa trap signifies that one of the LSA in the router's link-state database has aged to MaxAge.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfLsdbAreaId %parm[#2]%;

ospfLsdbType %parm[#3]%;

ospfLsdbLsid %parm[#4]%;

ospfLsdbRouterId %parm[#5]%;
event.logmsg: ospfMaxAgeLsaV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfLsdbAreaId=%parm[#2]% ospfLsdbType=%parm[#3]% ospfLsdbLsid=%parm[#4]% ospfLsdbRouterId=%parm[#5]%

event.descr:
An ospfLsdbOverflow trap signifies that the number of LSAs in the router's link-state data- base has exceeded ospfExtLsdbLimit.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfExtLsdbLimit %parm[#2]%;
event.logmsg: ospfLsdbOverflowV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfExtLsdbLimit=%parm[#2]%

event.descr:
An ospfLsdbApproachingOverflow trap signifies that the number of LSAs in the router's link- state database has exceeded ninety percent of ospfExtLsdbLimit.

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfExtLsdbLimit %parm[#2]%;
event.logmsg: ospfLsdbApproachingOverflowV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfExtLsdbLimit=%parm[#2]%

event.descr:
An ospfIfStateChange trap signifies that there has been a change in the state of a non-virtual OSPF interface. This trap should be generated when the interface state regresses (e.g., goes from Dr to Down) or progresses to a terminal state (i.e., Point-to-Point, DR Other, Dr, or Backup).

ospfRouterId %parm[#1]%;

ospfIfIpAddress %parm[#2]%;

ospfAddressLessIf %parm[#3]%;

ospfIfState %parm[#4]%;
event.logmsg: ospfIfStateChangeV1 trap received ospfRouterId=%parm[#1]% ospfIfIpAddress=%parm[#2]% ospfAddressLessIf=%parm[#3]% ospfIfState=%parm[#4]%
